titleStmt.title: Ninisina and the gods (Ninisina F) -- an English prose translation

publicationStmt.distributor: The Electronic Text Corpus of Sumerian Literature

address.addrLine: The Oriental Institute, University of Oxford, Pusey Lane, Oxford OX1 2LE, UK, email etcsl@orinst.ox.ac.uk, http://etcsl.orinst.ox.ac.uk

seriesStmt.p: The Electronic Text Corpus of Sumerian Literature aims to make accessible over 400 literary works composed in the Sumerian language in ancient Mesopotamia during the late third and early second millennia BC. The works are in Sumerian composite transliteration and English prose translation with bibliographical information on each composition.

sourceDesc.p: Sources are listed in the header of the composite text

div1.p: They &X;&X; stood around her. The holy and pure divine powers befit Ninisina, lady of the great divine powers. Her divine powers are divine powers bestowed on her by An. The Great Mountain Enlil determined a fate for her.

Having left the temple of Enlil, she entered Eridug, the pleasant place, and took her seat in the abzu shrine. Her father, Enki, seated her upon his knees. He truly cherished Ninisina -- as soon as &X;&X; took a fancy to jewels of &c;uba stone, they were hung around the neck of Ninisina; as soon as she took a fancy to a white linen garment, he dressed the daughter of holy An in it. Lord Nudimmud determined a fate for her.
She lay down with him on &X;&X; and spent time joyously with him.

&X;&X; with your beloved spouse, Lord Pabilsa&g;, &X;&X; your chosen &X;&X;! This is what the Great Mountain Enlil determined as her fate for &X;&X; perfect with the great divine powers, the fifty divine powers, &X;&X; perfect &X;&X; adorned with jewels of &c;uba stone, the lady whose great name &X;&X;.
In the shrine of Nibru, Dur-an-ki, the place of Enlil, she is &X;&X; indeed.

&X;&X; she is indeed &X;&X;. In &X;&X;, the &X;&X; of An, &X;&X; she is indeed &G;atumdug. In &X;&X;, her &X;&X; that reaches the heavens, she is indeed &X;&X;, the firstborn child. In &X;&X; &G;irsu, the shrine which first brought forth the seed of mankind, my lady is indeed Mother Bau. In &X;&X; Umma, in the &C;eg-kur&c;aga, &X;&X; she is indeed &X;&X;. In &X;&X;
In &X;&X;, a dragon lying in wait for men, a &X;&X; sticking out its tongue at everybody, my lady is indeed Nungal.

My lady entered Laga&c;. With her beloved spouse, Lord Pabilsa&g;, she &X;&X; the holy city, her chosen place. All the &X;&X; were drinking and enjoying &X;&X;. She gave them &X;&X;. She lay down with him on &X;&X; and spent time joyously with him.
&X;&X; Ninisina, it is sweet to praise you.
